'''Alexey Yakovlevich Chervonenkis''' ({{lang-ru|link=no|Алексей Яковлевич Червоненкис}}; 7 September 1938 – 22 September 2014) was a Soviet and Russian mathematician, and, with [[Vladimir Vapnik]], was one of the main developers of the [[Vapnik–Chervonenkis theory]], also known as the "fundamental theory of learning"  an important part of [[computational learning theory]]. Chervonenkis held joint appointments with the [[Russian Academy of Sciences]] and [[Royal Holloway, University of London]].<ref name="guard">{{cite news|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/sep/25/university-of-london-maths-professor-found-dead-moscow|title=University of London maths professor found dead in Moscow park|publisher=The Guardian|date=25 September 2014}}</ref> 

Alexey Chervonenkis got lost in [[Losiny Ostrov National Park]] on 22 September 2014, and later during a search operation was found dead near [[Mytishchi]], a suburb of Moscow.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kp.ru/daily/26285/3163696/|script-title=ru:Известный ученый Алексей Червоненкис погиб в Москве|publisher=kp.ru|date=23 September 2014|language=Russian}}</ref> He had died of [[hypothermia]].<ref name="guard"/>
